awd_titl_txt: Coaching toward the Professoriate: Race and Gender Conscious Mentoring for Black Doctoral Students in Engineering and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Across the nation, there is a dearth of underrepresented faculty in engineering and computing, and many explanations have been presented to explain the shortages in popular and scientific literature. Over the years, a plethora of strategies, initiatives, and programs have been created to address the broadening participation challenges in the engineering professoriate, but minimum visible gains have been achieved. This project is closely aligned with a long-standing interest of the National Science Foundation to increase the number of underrepresented faculty in the engineering and computing professoriate. By executing this project, the investigators expect that there will be an increase the number of Black engineering and social scientist faculty who are trained to serve as coaches and mentors for scholars from underrepresented groups at the crucial, pre-faculty career stage; increase in the number of diverse doctoral and postdoctoral scholars who become employed as engineering and computing faculty; and improvement of the success rate of Black engineering and computing faculty through the tenure process. As way of increasing the number of underrepresented groups who enter the engineering professoriate, the project's plan comprised the following: 

(1) Developing effective materials for coaching-based mentorship of future engineering faculty.
(2) Recruiting and training current tenured faculty in engineering and social science to serve as coaches 
(3) Implementing the coaching-based mentorship. 
(4) Implementing a plan to sustain the coaching-based mentorship beyond the project funding.
(5) Implementing a plan to sustain the coaching-based mentorship beyond the project funding.
(6) Coordinating and assessing the coaching-based mentorship. 

Guided by the theoretical and scientific literature on Communities of Practice (CoP) and Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT), the investigators outlined a comprehensive project to develop and implement a coaching-based mentoring program to enhance approaches to diversify the engineering and computing professoriate and to develop methods to teach and train tenured engineering and social science faculty effective mentoring skills. For this project, the investigators plan to extend this mentoring intervention to 40 underrepresented doctoral and postdoctoral scholars in engineering and computing, with a particular focus on those who are interested in pursuing faculty positions. Additionally, the plan includes the services of an external evaluator, who will execute multi-level, multi-phased, mixed methods data collections from all the key project stakeholders (e.g., coaches, mentees, postdoctoral manager, graduate students, and the investigators. This project is timely and likely to help improve engineering success outcomes in the professoriate and doctoral programs.

por.por_cntn:
Coaching Toward the Professoriate: Race- and Gender-Conscious Mentoring for Black Doctoral Students in Engineering and Computing

Rapid changes in technology, innovation, racial and ethnic demographics, national security, and globalization are driving the need for both a more diverse engineering workforce and a more diverse engineering professoriate. Research indicates that faculty of color enhance the recruitment, retention, and success of students of color, not only by serving as role models, but also by showing that successful careers in academic engineering are viable and attainable. However, students of color lack mentoring relationships—especially with faculty of the same race. Women students are even less likely to have mentoring relationships with women of color faculty.

Coaching for the Professoriate is a creative non-traditional coaching-based mentoring program grounded in engineering and social science research (social psychology; sociology; education) that motivates students while educating them. This is a research-based project that builds on extensive reviews of research, policies, programs, and practices that show what works—and what does not work—for Black men and women in traditional coaching and mentoring programs.

We designed and implemented this virtual, non-traditional, race- and gender-conscious coaching-based mentoring program for Black Ph.D. engineering and computing students interested in a career in the professoriate. This project sought not only to encourage diversity in the engineering and computing professoriate, but also to develop novel methods of teaching mentoring skills. It also provided training to tenured engineering and social science faculty. In addition, the PIs plan to develop and implement a plan to sustain the coaching-based mentorship model beyond the funded portion of the project. 

In this project, we established cohorts with a common framework: three groups each consisting of two coaches and five PhD students at various points in their careers. Within each group, we divided coaches and participants equally by gender. All of the coaches were tenured Black faculty—one engineer and one social scientist. Our strategy was to select coaches with experience in and commitment to mentoring/coaching PhD students toward choosing a career as a faculty member. We sought to capitalize on these mentors’ expertise and leverage their experiences as object lessons for the students. Because coaches were/had been in academic leadership positions, they could put the hiring, tenure, and promotion processes in a broader context—not only at the department level but also at the college and university level.

These sessions were structured using a flipped classroom model in which coaches and student participants watched videos to establish a starting point for each session and a common universe of discourse among the groups. A shared vocabulary is especially important, since there are terms with which participants may be unfamiliar, such as “microaggressions” or “imposter syndrome.” We required participants to watch one video before each session. Videos ranged in length from 22 to 39 minutes. Participants rated the videos on a scale of 1 to 10 (1=not interesting in the slightest; 10 = totally interesting/engaging). There was a consensus among participants’ assessments of the videos. The two videos that students found most interesting/engaging were “A Brief History of Race in America,” and “The History of the Black Experience in Predominantly White Institutions.” In these sessions, coaches also provided students with strategies on how to be successful if they find themselves in an environment that promotes impostorism and other forms of racial bias.

We also found that students were largely unaware of the differences in academic careers between different types/classifications of institutions: HBCUs; majority institutions; Carnegie Classification - RI, etc. Our coaches responded by co-creating an additional workshop on what it means to be a faculty member at these different types of institutions. They highlighted these differences to ensure that students had the information they needed to consider the full breadth of their opportunities in academia. After each session, coaches discussed what worked and what could have worked better. As the program progressed, student participants gradually came to envision themselves as part of an engineering or computing faculty. We believe that race-conscious paired mentoring can serve as a bridge to motivating Black doctoral students to pursue faculty positions and, more importantly, to thrive in them.
